newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ shares close firmer despite RBNZ warning.
newsitem.headline: NZ shares close firmer despite RBNZ warning.

text.p: * NZ shares shrug off RBNZ comment that monetary conditions are too easy
* higher rates could prompt equity consolidation next week.
Price movements at close
LAST CHG * NZSE40 cap index +9.64 at 2,516.84

New Zealand share prices ended higher on Friday despite a warning from the Reserve Bank that monetary conditions were too loose.
The NZSE-40 Capital Index closed 9.64 points stronger at 2,516.84, with all leading stocks firmer.
An unexpectedly large current account deficit for the March quarter, released this morning, caused a sharp fall in the New Zealand dollar and a spike higher in short interest rates.
That saw monetary conditions ease to a point that the Reserve Bank, which wants to keep underlying inflation between zero and three percent, could not tolerate.
"Overall monetary conditions have settled too far from the Reserve Bank's desired monetary conditions," governor Don Brash warned the markets.
But the statement, released 40 minutes before session's end, was largely ignored in the equity market.
"It was end of the day, people were finishing up orders, and the market tended to ignore those comments," said Craig Robins at County Natwest.
But he said the market may react to the comments next week.
"Obviously the Reserve Bank is signalling slightly tighter conditions are more desirable, so I think we'll get more of a consolidation than we've had."

Lion Nathan stood out on the day, rising six cents to $3.88. Brokers said the rise reflected a better outlook for the brewer's Australian operations, which account for about 70 percent of its earnings.
Fletcher Energy continued its good recent run, rising a further 10 cents to $4.85, but FCL Forest came under pressure and ended eight cents weaker at $2.02.
